title: Deep Learning Architectures for Fatigue Detection
section_id: 3.2 Deep Learning Architectures for Fatigue Detection
description: Discuss in detail the architectures mentioned in section 4.2 (CNNs, RNNs, Autoencoders, DBNs, GANs, GCNs), providing specific examples of their application in fatigue detection.

CNN.description: Utilizes a modified Inception-dilated ResNet for EEG-based fatigue detection.
Employs a CNN for automated drowsiness detection from single-channel EEG.
Uses a CNN architecture for drowsiness detection from EEG signals.
Applies a 12-layer ConvNets model for automated fatigue recognition.
Uses CNNs to analyze EEG signals for fatigue detection without manual feature extraction.
Combines phase-based functional connectivity with CNN for detecting unfavorable driving states.
Transforms EEG signals into spatial RGB images for CNN-based drowsiness prediction.
Introduces an interpretable CNN-LSTM model for subject-independent drowsiness recognition.
Presents a compact and interpretable CNN for cross-subject driver drowsiness detection.
Proposes an interpretable CNN for calibration-free EEG-based driver drowsiness recognition.
Utilizes a cascaded CNN with an attention mechanism for mobile EEG-based drowsiness detection.
Presents a 1D-CNN and pre-trained neural networks for automatic drowsiness detection.

RNN.description: Introduces ACF-GCN, improving reaction time estimations based on EEG signals.
Employs LSTM networks as classifiers in a hybrid model for drowsiness detection.
Proposes SACC-CapsNet for EEG-based driving fatigue detection, utilizing LSTM for improved learning.
Uses an interpretable CNN-LSTM model for subject-independent drowsiness recognition.
Introduces an LSTM network with a capsule attention mechanism for driver vigilance estimation.
Proposes an LSTM network with a capsule attention mechanism for driver vigilance estimation.
Integrates LSTM for sequential data learning in a multimodal tensor fusion network for fatigue recognition.

Autoencoder.description: Includes an autoencoder among dimensionality reduction techniques for microsleep detection from EEG.
Presents a neural network ensemble using stacked denoising autoencoders (SDAEs) for cognitive load identification from EEG.
Discusses an architecture that could be extended to include autoencoders for unsupervised feature learning.

DBN.description: Employs sparse-DBN for EEG-based driver fatigue detection, showing improved classification performance.

GAN.description: Uses a GAN (mTGAN) for data augmentation to enhance drowsiness recognition.
Incorporates a GAN to augment data in the GARMFCN-LSTM model, addressing class imbalance.

GCN.description: Utilizes ACF-GCN for EEG signal analysis, targeting fatigue-related frequency bands.
Proposes a GCN-based approach for detecting mental fatigue by analyzing EEG inter-channel connectivity.
Introduces MAFNs, utilizing GCNs implicitly through network analysis for fatigue and brain disease diagnosis.

Hybrid.description: Proposes a hybrid deep neural network approach using a modified Inception-dilated ResNet for fatigue detection.
Introduces a hybrid model combining statistical and deep learning features for EEG-based drowsiness detection.
Presents SACC-CapsNet, a hybrid model for EEG-based driving fatigue detection.
Proposes an interpretable CNN-LSTM model for subject-independent drowsiness recognition.
Proposes a hybrid model integrating LSTM with a capsule attention mechanism.
Proposes a hybrid model integrating LSTM with a capsule attention mechanism.
Proposes a hybrid model of pre-trained neural networks and a custom 1D-CNN for drowsiness detection.
Introduces ARMFCN-LSTM and GARMFCN-LSTM, hybrid models for fatigue detection.

all_upper_levels.title: The Role of Deep Learning and Hybrid Models
all_upper_levels.section_id: 3. The Role of Deep Learning and Hybrid Models
